posts.name: Shlomit
posts.cooked:
Our team’s been working on improving our electronics layout and cable management this off-season. We’ve seen how bad cable routing can cause all sorts of problems: loose connections, damaged wires, and even weird robot behavior during matches. So now we’re trying to be more intentional about how we do things.

I wanted to open a discussion and learn from other teams:

What tools or materials do you use for clean and reliable cable management?

Do you have any go-to techniques or rules your team follows (e.g., labeling wires, CADing before, soldering)?

Any cool tips for making electronics easier to debug mid-match?

Some things we’re already using:

Zip ties (of course)

Heat shrink for protecting connections

Wagos

cable bundlers

energy belt

I’d really love to hear how teams manage their electronics!

Shlomit :

Wagos

I personally am not a big fan of wagos. I like anderson power poles more because

a) they’re a one and done kind of deal. after you crimp them on once, you can just slide them on whenever, and dont have to deal with bunched up wires from removing them from a connector a lot of times (think Spark MAX wires) b) you can ziptie powerpoles together so that they don’t slide off of each other c) they can b e slid together to make a big block of powerpoles that can be easily unplugged or plugged in together

However, if you do plan on using WAGO’s, I really love this video from Team 11.

Something else that also helps is having nice wire that can easily be flexed around and moved. We had really crusty wire that was a pain to turn, until we got some new wire from PowerWerx, which has been 200% better since we can actually bend the damn thing.

There is also a lot of great information in this thread .

posts.name: Shlomit
posts.cooked: We used Andersons this year too. We found it harder to crimp every single one, so for most uses we ended up using wagos. However we did use andersons for the NEO 550. Maybe we were doing them wrong, but we struggled more with them and found them less reliable especially with bendy wires.

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
A couple suggestions for PowerPoles:

See if you can find the “SF” (“Super Flex”) versions of the PowerPole crimp contacts. (See this older catalogue , and for example part 200G3L .) They are designed for 10 AWG, fine-stranded wire, and ought to be crimpable with regular tools (TriCrimp or APP factory tooling). The maximum intended wire cross-sectional area is 6.0 mm 2 , instead of 5.3 mm 2 for the regular ones.

Use a pair of tiny needle-nosed pliers, in the back of the housing and diagonally in the square corners, to grip the back of the contact and set it past the click of the housing spring. With small, stiff wire, you don’t need this; with flexible, large wire, it comes in very handy.

Maybe tiny zip ties within the holes between the two housings would work for retention? This could be in addition to, or instead of the high detent force (high mating force) contacts, which aren’t as widely available and are difficult to error-proof. Strong clear tape with a sticky, no-residue adhesive, wrapped and with a little folded over tab for easy removal works pretty well too.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Tristan_Lall:

Use a pair of tiny needle-nosed pliers, in the back of the housing and diagonally in the square corners, to grip the back of the contact and set it past the click of the housing spring. With small, stiff wire, you don’t need this; with flexible, large wire, it comes in very handy.

There’s actually a tool for inserting contacts into housings, although I’ve never seen a team use it. It’s a plastic cone that goes on the outside of the wire and pushes on the metal contact. We use these regularly at work for inserting pins into connectors.

For 12 gauge wires use M81969-14-04, these are only a few dollars and might save you some headaches.

image 1038×809 64.1 KB

image 1038×809 64.1 KB

image 1038×809 64.1 KB

Andersons for power, solder everything else. For quick tests, DuPonts and Wagos work well, alongside Weidmullers for ferrules. Also, use loom or cable track when it comes to long strips of wire in exposed areas. Other than that your list looks good.

Outside of the equipment perspective, the paradigm I’ve always followed is to create cable pathways all around the robot; that is, every single cable must go through one of these paths. Usually your paths will be decided by the rest of your robot; for example, our robot this year was very simple and the final pathway was basically just a square.

Some more small tips (no particular order or category):

Utilize open spaces in tubes to protect and guide wires.

Expose entire mechanisms to the robot by as few points as possible. 1 power pair for each MC and 2 CAN connectors. Solder all the CAN together to make them into coherent units. This makes swapping in backups easier.

1 power pair for each MC and 2 CAN connectors.

Solder all the CAN together to make them into coherent units.

This makes swapping in backups easier.

Use hot glue for sketchy/important connections: RSL , RIO/ PDH CAN , any DIO/ PWM ports

Avoid bending crimps too sharply

When soldering, twist the wires together to maximize cohesion before soldering. AND PLEASE USE FLUX!

CAD your electronics, both for cable management/MC placement and for knowing the true weight of the robot. You will not regret this.

Recruit musicians and/or artists to your electrical subteam. Seriously. This actually works really well.

Seriously. This actually works really well.

Add a small amount of slack when cutting wires, both to reduce stress and to give a bit of extra leeway.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: We mainly used energy chain and zipties this year and they worked really well.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
Tristan_Lall:

Maybe tiny zip ties within the holes between the two housings would work

Powerwerx actually makes little inserts for that exact purpose .

1732 uses 3D printed clips that look like this:

9k= 1200×900 94.4 KB

9k= 1200×900 94.4 KB

9k= 1200×900 94.4 KB

We do not use WAGOs for anything high-current, except those built into the PDH . After another year of learning, we may abandon WAGOs entirely next year. Andersons for power, JST-XH for sensors, and solder loaded heat shrink butt splices for CAN .

Tristan_Lall:

Maybe tiny zip ties within the holes between the two housings would work for retention?

You can also zip tie around the entire connector and between the wires instead of threading the tiny holes. Going around the outsize allows for larger zip ties too; I’ve found that the super-tiny ones are a bit more fiddly to source and install than standard ones.

To OP, 2102 sleeves everything , especially wires we don’t expect to handle often like bellypan wiring. It gives more protection to external runs, or can act like an outer sheath for moving cables. Being able to see major pathways to individual modules/mechanisms also helps a ton when troubleshooting.

The weight penalty is minimal when using thin stuff like split-loom sleeving . If you do sleeve wiring, work against hiding connectors inside sleeves. They’re surprisingly easy to forget to check when tracing wires.

Seconding others; avoid wagos, hot glue small connectors that can’t easily be zip tied, and plan out wiring when designing your robot.

posts.name: Vaani Mathur
posts.cooked:
crueter:

Recruit musicians and/or artists to your electrical subteam.

Elaborate :0?

Edit: Just realized why: nimble fingers :)!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: officially washed as the kids say

posts.cooked: Nimble fingers yes, but artistic ability also provably increases electrical capability; primarily by having an increased sense of direction with managing complex wires. Some would even call cable management art in and of itself.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: I am not electronic master but I know this year we wired everything under our belly pan and then we just had a bunch of wire loom and sticky back.

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: One thing that helped our wire management this year was doing a hole pattern on our bellypan so then we can easily move 3dp and run zipties through the bellypan without worrying about stickybacks. It also makes your wiring cleaner, and you can move subsystems a lot easier

What specifically did you struggle with? Crimping the contact onto the wire? Inserting into the housing, or housings slipping apart? Also what size contacts do you use (we use PP45)?

I also recommend the PowerWerx TriCrimp tool (its what we use and its great).
